pullRequest.body:
Prove Lie's theorem, that Lie modules of solvable Lie algebras over algebraically closed fields of characteristic 0 have a common eigenvector for the action of all elements of the Lie algebra.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
Hello: I'm coming here for issue triage. You marked this PR as `help-wanted`: can you be more specific what help you need? This makes it easier for other to help you :-)
The lint and build is certainly easy to fix: let me just do this.

Oh, and another comment: did you mean to mark this ready for review? If so, feel free to label it `awaiting-review` once you have addressed my comments. (I've marked it with `awaiting-author` now: see this page for an explanation what these labels mean: https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html)

Last, but not least: thank you for your contribution! I'm very happy that mathlib is learning more about Lie groups and Lie algebras and very much look forward to your result landing, once it's ready!

Thank you very much for the help @grunweg. I marked this as `help-wanted` since I didn't really understand why continuous integration was failing but you seemed to have fixed this now. I'll get to work on resolving the things you've brought up.

By the way: once you have dealt with a comment, feel free to mark it as "resolved" in Github. This way, I and future reviews can see which points are still open or not. If you're not sure, leaving it open is fine (but in practice, for many suggestions it's clear once they were resolved).

### PR summary

#### Import changes

No significant changes to the import graph

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ LieIdeal.incl_injective`
`+ LieModule.exists_forall_lie_eq_smul_finrank`
`+ LieModule.exists_forall_lie_eq_smul_of_Solvable`
`+ T_apply_succ`
`+ T_map_iSup_iteratedRange`
`+ T_map_iteratedRange_nilpotent`
`+ T_res_nilpotent`
`+ altWeightSpace`
`+ altWeightSpace_lie_stable`
`+ chi_az_zero`
`+ derivedSeries_eq_top`
`+ derivedSeries_ne_top_of_solvable`
`+ exists_hasEigenvalue_of_iSup_genEigenspace_eq_top`
`+ exists_lieIdeal_of_derivedSeries_le`
`+ extend_weight`
`+ iSup_eq_iteratedRange`
`+ iSup_iteratedRange_A_stable`
`+ instance (I : LieIdeal R L) [IsTriangularizable R L M] : IsTriangularizable R I M`
`+ instance (L' : LieSubalgebra R L) [IsTriangularizable R L M] : IsTriangularizable R L' M`
`+ instance : IsCoatomic (Submodule k V)`
`+ instance [IsTriangularizable R L M] : IsTriangularizable R (LieModule.toEnd R L M).range M`
`+ iteratedRange_map`
`+ iteratedRange_mono`
`+ iteratedRange_zero_eq_bot`
`+ map_iteratedRange_iSup_le_iSup`
`+ map_iteratedRange_le`
`+ trace_T_res_zero`
`+ trace_πaz`
`+ trace_πaz_zero`
`+ πaz_map_iSup_iteratedRange`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>
I left a few style comments to get you started (and just pushed the fix to Mathlib.lean, so mathlib's continuous integration can give you feedback).
Thanks for the quick response! I had some time at my hands and decided to leave a few more comments, mostly about coding style. (This covers perhaps the first half of your PR.)

There already is an api for turning complementary submodules into a direct sum. With my current suggestion, you can remove your `pr1` and `pr2` declarations.

You may also want to assume `IsCompl` in more places, instead of separe (Co)Disjoint hypotheses.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion rw [← hx]; exact Submodule.zero_mem _ ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ∀ x ∈ iSupU v (π k V z), (T A χ w) x ∈ iSupU v (π k V z) := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ∀ x ∈ (iSupU v (π k V z)), (π k V w) x ∈ (iSupU v (π k V z)):= by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ∀ x ∈ (U_map v (π k V z)) N, (T A χ w ^ N) x = 0 := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion IsNilpotent ((T A χ w).restrict (T_map_iSupU A χ z w hv)) := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion LinearMap.trace k (iSupU v (π k V z)) ((T A χ w).restrict (T_map_iSupU A χ z w hv)) = 0 := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ∀ x ∈ iSupU v (π k V z), π k V ⁅a,z⁆ x ∈ iSupU v (π k V z):= by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion LinearMap.trace k (iSupU v (π k V z)) ((π k V ⁅a, z⁆).restrict (πaz_map_iSupU A χ z a hv)) ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion LinearMap.trace k (iSupU v (π k V z)) ((π k V ⁅a, z⁆).restrict (πaz_map_iSupU A χ z a hv)) ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (lieIdealSubalgebra k L (LieAlgebra.derivedSeries k L 1)).toSubmodule ≠ ⊤ := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion simp? ```

This option is the default in mathlib: you can simply remove this line
```suggestion

Can you be more specific: such as, what is the precise statement you're formalising?

I presume your file includes other definitions or noteworthy lemmas on the way; can you mention these here as well? (In case you haven't read them, here's the documentation guide: https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/doc.html

This name will be hard to understand from the outside: can you give this a more descriptive name?
(You can use `local notation` to still name it `U` in this file --- but it will have a clearer name to the outside.)

And also, this is currently in the root namespace, i.e. anyone who imports this and want to have `(U : Set X)` as an open space will get an error. Can you wrap the whole file in `namespace LieModule`, so that the theorems will be called `LieModule.*` outside this file.

The documentation linter will tell you this once this builds: please add a docstring to all new definitions.

Documentation for lemmas is optional, for theorems, you should also add one (but that's currently not enforced yet).
Can you combine these into one line? Similarly below.
I would remove this line break.

A comment on style: in general, we prefer to put spaces around binary operators (like the dot) or the vertical bar.
This also applies in other places, please make the same change there.
```suggestion
  carrier := {v | ∀ a : A, ⁅a.val, v⁆ = (χ a) • v}
```

(*Just in case* you haven't seen it already, mathlib's style guide is here: https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html)

As I understand it, mathlib style is to have no blank lines between the different fields of a definition.
```suggestion

I think you can replace this entire sub-proof by (untested)
```suggestion
  zero_mem' := by rw [lie_zero, smul_zero]
```
similarly below
this doesn't seem to work. `zero_mem' := fun _ => by rw [lie_zero, smul_zero]` does work, but I don't know if this is preserved over what I had before

Right, I meant `zero_mem' _ := by rw [lie_zero, smul_zero]`. Sorry for the confusion!
This is equivalent to `zero_mem' := fun _ => by rw [lie_zero, smul_zero]`, and equivalent to what you wrote before.

In general, we try to be careful with including explicit arguments as variables; often it's better to provide them as explicit arguments to all the definitions/lemmas that need them. Can these become implicit? (For these two, I could expect them to.)

If you just want to make them explicit in one declaration, you can do `variable (k V) in` just before the declaration.
Again: can these become implicit? For instance, in the `abbrev T`, I would assume `A` can be inferred from `w`.
Similar comment here, about explicit arguments in `variable`s.

Does this fit on one line, as in ` have  : ⁅w.val, (π k V z ^ n) v⁆ = (T A χ w) ((π k V z ^ n) v) + χ w  • ((π k V z ^ n) v) := by`? (You also have some double spaces in this line; please remove those.)

In general, mathlib style is to put hypotheses "left of the colon": instead of having a conclusion "for all x, bla", we prefer to add `x` as an explicit argument and just have "bla" as the conclusion. This helps a lot when using `rw` with your lemmas.
Can you do this here, and in all other places below where this applies?
Then the `intro` line is also superfluous.
Mathlib style is to use two-space indentation here.

At this point, you're creating two sub-goals: in such a case, mathlib style asks for focusing dots · (inserted as \.).

In fact, I wonder: can you complete the proof of the `have` directly? This would be even clearer, to me.
This line can be removed now, right?
I create a copy of `hW1` so that I can transform one of them with rewrites and keep the other as a hypothesis. This is probably bad style so I'll try something else
Is it possible to obtain a result without assuming `IsAlgClosed k` if we assume `LieModule.IsTriangularizable k L V`?
I unexpectedly had a few minutes to spare this afternoon so I just pushed a commit with this generalisation.

```suggestion
theorem LieModule.exists_forall_lie_eq_smul_finrank :
    ∀ (L : Type*) [LieRing L] [LieAlgebra k L] [FiniteDimensional k L] [IsSolvable k L]
      [LieRingModule L V] [LieModule k L V],
      ∃ χ : Module.Dual k L, ∃ v : V, v ≠ 0 ∧ ∀ x : L, ⁅x, v⁆ = χ x • v := by
  intro L _ _ _ _ _ _
  obtain _inst|_inst := subsingleton_or_nontrivial L
  · rcases (exists_ne (0 : V)) with ⟨v, hv⟩
    use 0, v, hv
    intro x
    simp only [Subsingleton.elim x 0, zero_lie, map_zero, zero_smul]
  obtain H|⟨A, hcoatomA, hAL⟩ := eq_top_or_exists_le_coatom (derivedSeries k L 1 : Submodule k L)
  · exact (derivedSubalgebra_ne_top H).elim

  obtain ⟨z, hz⟩ : ∃ (z : L), z ∉ A := by
    by_contra! h
    apply hcoatomA.1
    rw [eq_top_iff]
    exact fun ⦃x⦄ _ => h x
  set B := Submodule.span k {z} with hBdef

  have htopdecomp : A ⊔ B = ⊤ := by
    apply hcoatomA.2
    rw [left_lt_sup]
    contrapose! hz with h
    exact h <| Submodule.mem_span_singleton_self z

  have hAinterB : A ⊓ B = ⊥ := by
    rw [hBdef, ← le_bot_iff]
    rintro x ⟨(ha : x ∈ A), (hb : x ∈ Submodule.span k _)⟩
    obtain ⟨c, rfl⟩ : ∃ c, c • z = x := by rwa [Submodule.mem_span_singleton] at hb
    apply A.smul_mem c⁻¹ at ha
    rcases eq_or_ne c 0 with (rfl | hc) <;> simp_all

  obtain ⟨A, rfl⟩ : ∃ A' : LieIdeal k L, A = A'.toSubmodule :=
    exists_lieIdeal_of_derivedSeries_le _ hAL
  have hAsolv : LieAlgebra.IsSolvable k A := A.incl_injective.lieAlgebra_isSolvable

  obtain ⟨χ', v, hv, hvA⟩ := LieModule.exists_forall_lie_eq_smul_finrank A
  apply extend_weight A z hz htopdecomp hAinterB χ' v hv hvA
termination_by L _ _ _ => finrank k L
decreasing_by
  simp_wf
  rw [← finrank_top k L]
  apply Submodule.finrank_lt_finrank_of_lt
  rw [← covBy_top_iff] at hcoatomA
  exact hcoatomA.1
```

```suggestion
  have aux : IsCompl A.toSubmodule (Submodule.span k {z}) := ⟨hdis, hcodis⟩
  have hz' : z ≠ 0 := by
    rintro rfl
    apply hz <| A.zero_mem

  let π1 := A.toSubmodule.linearProjOfIsCompl (Submodule.span k {z}) aux
  let π2 := (Submodule.span k {z}).linearProjOfIsCompl ↑A aux.symm

  use (χ'.comp π1) + c • ((kequivB z hz').symm.comp π2), v'
  constructor
  · have := hv''.right
    rw [ne_eq]
    intro h
    apply this
    apply (Submodule.mk_eq_zero _ _).mpr h
  · intro x
    have π1_add_π2 : (π1 x : L) + π2 x = x :=
      Submodule.linear_proj_add_linearProjOfIsCompl_eq_self aux x
    nth_rw 1 [← π1_add_π2, add_lie]
    rw [hv' (π1 x), LinearMap.add_apply, LinearMap.comp_apply, add_smul, add_right_inj]
    simp only [LieIdeal.coe_to_lieSubalgebra_to_submodule, LinearMap.smul_apply, LinearMap.coe_comp,
      LinearEquiv.coe_coe, Function.comp_apply, smul_eq_mul]
    rcases Submodule.mem_span_singleton.mp ((π2 x).prop) with ⟨d, hd⟩
    rw [← hd, smul_lie]
    have : ⁅z, v'⁆ = πz_res ⟨v', hv'⟩ := rfl
    rw [this, Module.End.HasEigenvector.apply_eq_smul hv'', mul_comm, mul_smul]
    simp only [SetLike.mk_smul_mk]
    congr 2
    rw [LinearEquiv.eq_symm_apply]
    ext
    exact hd
```
This instance can move elsewhere, outside the Lie theory folder.
This is no longer used.

```suggestion
    (hcodis : A.toSubmodule ⊔ (k ∙ z) = ⊤)
```
Also in other places

This already exists: so I think you can just inline it.
```suggestion
noncomputable def kequivB (z : L) (hz : z ≠ 0) : k ≃ₗ[k] k ∙ z :=
  LinearEquiv.toSpanNonzeroSingleton k _ z hz
```

```suggestion
  obtain H|⟨A, hcoatomA, hAL⟩ := eq_top_or_exists_le_coatom (derivedSeries k L 1).toSubmodule
  · rw [LieSubmodule.coeSubmodule_eq_top_iff] at H
    exact (derivedSeries_ne_top_of_solvable k L H).elim
```
With this change, I think you can drop the lemma `derivedSubalgebra_ne_top`.

As suggested above:
```suggestion
  set B := k ∙ z with hBdef
```
And I think with this short notation you could even drop the notation `B` and just use `k ∙ z` inline.

```suggestion
  obtain ⟨c, hc⟩ := Module.End.exists_eigenvalue πz_res
```

```suggestion
abbrev T (w : A) : Module.End k V := (π w) - χ w • 1

/-- The common eigenvectors of `V` with respect to the action of all elements in
the Lie Ideal `A`.-/
def altWeightSpace : Submodule k V :=
  (⨅ w : A, (LinearMap.ker (M := V) (T A χ w))).copy {v | ∀ a : A, ⁅a.val, v⁆ = (χ a) • v} <| by
  ext v
  simp only [Subtype.forall, Set.mem_setOf_eq, T, Submodule.iInf_coe, Set.mem_iInter,
    SetLike.mem_coe, LinearMap.mem_ker, LinearMap.sub_apply, LieModule.toEnd_apply_apply,
    LinearMap.smul_apply, LinearMap.one_apply, sub_eq_zero]

```suggestion
lemma trace_πaz (a : A) (hv : v ∈ altWeightSpace A χ) :
```

```suggestion
theorem trace_πaz_zero (a : A) (hv : v ∈ altWeightSpace A χ) :
```

```suggestion
lemma chi_az_zero (a : A) (hv : v ∈ altWeightSpace A χ) (hv' : v ≠ 0) :
```

```suggestion
    rw [leibniz_lie, hv a, hzwv, lie_smul, chi_az_zero A χ z a hv hv', zero_smul, zero_add]
```

```suggestion
theorem altWeightSpace_lie_stable (hv : v ∈ altWeightSpace A χ) : ⁅z, v⁆ ∈ altWeightSpace A χ := by
```

```suggestion
    ∃ A' : LieIdeal k L, A = A' := by
  refine ⟨⟨A, ?_⟩, rfl⟩
  intro x m _
  exact h <| LieSubmodule.lie_mem_lie _ _ (LieSubmodule.mem_top _) (LieSubmodule.mem_top _)
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Algebra/Lie): add Lie's theorem
